Issues.Title: refactor(router): merge `RouterLink` and `RouterLinkWithHref` classes
Issues.Body:
IMPORTANT: this is a "work in progress" PR and it's missing the following items:
- `RouterLinkWithHref` -> `RouterLink` migration/schematic
- deprecation note for `RouterLinkWithHref` (in a commit and in deprecations guide)

This commit updates the Router packages code and merges `RouterLink` and `RouterLinkWithHref` classes into one. The motivation for this change is to improve the DX when those directives are used as standalone ones. Currently, developers need to either import `RouterLink` or `RouterLinkWithHref`, depending on whether a host element for the directive is an `<a>` tag or not. This is pretty inconvenient and when a wrong directive is imported, there are no errors or logs, which makes it harder to find the problem. Now the `RouterLink` can be imported and it would work for all host elements.

BREAKING CHANGE:

The `RouterLinkWithHref` directive was combined with `RouterLink`, which should be user instead. The `RouterLinkWithHref` is now an alias of the `RouterLink` and it's no longer a part of the `RouterModule`.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [x] Yes
- [ ] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(router): merge `RouterLink` and `RouterLinkWithHref` classes" (#47500)

Issues.Title: Introduce `NG_OPTIMIZED_IMAGE_CONFIG` token to configure image directive
Issues.Body:
NOTES:
- this PR is created on top of #47498 and will need a rebase once PR #47498 lands.
- more tests are needed to verify `NG_OPTIMIZED_IMAGE_CONFIG` token behavior

This commit replaces the `PRECONNECT_CHECK_BLOCKLIST` (used to configure a list of origins to skip preconnect check) with the `NG_OPTIMIZED_IMAGE_CONFIG` token that represents a consolidated config for `NgOptimizedImage` directives.

## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)

NOTE: marking it as a refactoring to land the change in the patch branch. The `NgOptimizedImage` directive is in the Developer Preview mode which allows us to update public APIs in patch releases.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Introduce `NG_OPTIMIZED_IMAGE_CONFIG` token to configure image directive" (#47499)

Issues.Title: fix(common): allow to skip preconnect check for loaders at the Component level
Issues.Body:
Previously, the `PreconnectLinkChecker` class (responsible for making sure preconnect tags exist for priority images) was not taking into account the `PRECONNECT_CHECK_BLOCKLIST` multi-provider token values provided on a @Component.providers level. This was a problem for built-in loaders added to the @Component.providers. The `PreconnectLinkChecker` class was effectively ignoring those tokens.

This commit updates the logic to retrieve the `PRECONNECT_CHECK_BLOCKLIST` multi-provider token values using a current directive injector instead, thus assembling a value that properly represents a config within a given DI tree.

## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Bugfix


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(common): allow to skip preconnect check for loaders at the Component level" (#47498)

Issues.Title: Improve the Stack Trace when an HTML Parsing Error is Encountered
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

I have noticed that when I make a syntax mistake in the HTML of a component the Angular Compiler throws a vast amount of errors, so much so that the original offending error is buried in a huge stack trace that is cut off in the terminal window of VS Code, my preferred Code Editor for Angular.  This can be worked around by exporting the stack trace to common error in the form a text file, however it would be very convenient if I could avoid these extra steps to identify the location of bad HTML.  

Ideally, when there is a syntax error in the HTML, I would like an option to be able to have the compiler simply identify the line where the HTML syntax is malformed and skip errors resulting from the malformed HTML syntax which would make the Stack Trace much more useful without needing to resort to workarounds for the issue.  

### Proposed solution

Introduce an option that suppresses all errors in a stack trace except for the first one when the error is caused by a malformed HTML element (syntax error).  

### Alternatives considered

A workaround is to export the output to a txt file and read the text file, but this can become cumbersome and adds friction to the normal workflow of a project.  Being able to simply and easily see where an HTML syntax error is located in the console without having to resort to the above workaround would be ideal.  

Below is an example of the top of the stack trace in VS Code and the syntax error that generated it.  Simply identifying the line with the error without showing all the additional errors would make the error output much more readable and useful

![Top of HTML syntax stack trace](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/114021657/191356925-85fafd97-efe3-46fe-8bb7-bfd1f7344d7e.PNG)
![Example Syntax Error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/114021657/191356928-f7f041ef-c76e-4849-9613-fa10e0e685f3.PNG)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Improve the Stack Trace when an HTML Parsing Error is Encountered" (#47496)

Issues.Title: Error Handler Service 'insider/client' exceptions (of type 'Error') not working when lazy loaded by parent application
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

We have multiple engineering groups working independently building Angular modules (NgModules). We keep these modules entirely independent and self-sufficient and, as such, have their own ErrorHandler overrides. The modules are route lazy loaded as needed into parent apps that require their functionality. Note, although not relevant, the modules are federated (see webpack) and are lazy loaded from other machines. But, for now, we don't believe their federation is the root cause of the issue.

The ErrorHandlers work fine and catch insider/client 'Error's when running in their own standalone apps. However, when loaded into the parent app which DOES NOT OVERRIDE their ErrorHandler's service, the insider Errors  are not caught. Important NOTE: The HTTPResponse/HttpErrorResponse, errors (ie outsider/server errors) ARE caught since each independent module calls their overridden ErrorHandler actively via the standard interceptor model-unike the insider/client errors that are called by Angular.

However, when we add an ErrorHandler to the parent, the insider/client Error exceptions do start getting called. Which subverts the modularity required and separation of concerns  of our modules. Note, it seems the ErrorHandler must provided at 'root' of any app that requires this feature. Submodules that have that feature are not invoked (except for outsider/server errors).

It 'seems the ErrorHandl

_No response_

```true
Angular 12.2.12
```

Issues.Title: refactor(core): remove assumptions that component will be first in directives list
Issues.Body:
`TNode`s have the `directiveStart` and `directiveEnd` properties that indicate the indexes at which directive instances (including components) have been stored. Currently there are several places throughout the codebase which assume that if a component matches a node, its index will always be `directiveStart`.

As far as I can tell, we probably ended up accumulating these assumptions, because we needed a quick way of accessing the component instance and it happened to be conventiently stored at `directiveStart`. The reason why it's always stored at `directiveStart` is likely to match the lifecycle hook execution order from ViewEngine.

With host directives these assumptions won't be valid anymore, because we want the host directives to _always_ execute before the host component that they're on so that the host has a chance to override them. To achieve this we have to insert host directives before the component.

These changes address the issue by introducing a new `TNode.componentOffset` property which indicates the offset after `TNode.directiveStart` at which the component is stored. Furthermore, I've removed the `isComponentHost` flag since it was duplicating the information from `TNode.componentOffset` and I've audited and fixed all the places where we read `directiveStart` to account for the changed data structure.

Reasons for some of the decisions I made along the way:
* In the case of host directives, I decided to go against our current convention of executing the component lifecycle hooks before the directive, because lifeycle hooks are a chance to change the component state (e.g. in `ngOnChanges`) and running the component hooks first would allow the host directives to undo any overrides made by the host.
* I decided to go with a `componentOffset`, instead of a `componentIndex` indicating the exact index the component is at, because as the runtime is set up at the moment, it would be difficult to know what index the component is going to end up at. Another problem is that we appear to have some logic that moves the entire "directive window" by incrementing both `directiveStart` and `directiveEnd`. By using an offset, we don't have to worry about the index remaining correct.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(core): remove assumptions that component will be first in directives list" (#47490)

Issues.Title: feat(compiler-cli): add `imgAltRequired` extended diagnostic
Issues.Body: This diagnostic requires that all `` tags have an `alt` attribute with a value. There are a few nuances to this: * `` is considered a mistake which emits a diagnostic. * By contrast, `` is considered valid and does _not_ emit a diagnostic because this signals to browsers that the image is decorative and can be ignored for a11y purposes. * See: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/img#attr-alt * `` checks if `altText` is "nullable" (can be `undefined` or `null`). If so, it emits a diagnostic adovising the user to remove those values from the type. Documentation elaborates on what an `alt` tag is, why you should write one, how to handle each subcase of this diagnostic, and how to turn off the check if desired. This commit also enables the extended diagnostic as a warning for all Angular projects by default. ## PR Checklist Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements: - [X] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit - [X] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features) - [X] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features) ## PR Type What kind of change does this PR introduce? - [X] Feature ## What is the current behavior? Issue Number: #46669 `` tags are allowed to not contain an `alt` attribute or contain an `alt` attribute bound to a property which can be `null` or `undefined`. These lead to poor accessibility, as screen readers and other assistive technologies cannot reason about the contents of an image and it is effectively invisible or opaque to many users. ## What is the new behavior? The Angular compiler emits a diagnostic (configurable severity, warning by default) which alerts the user when they author an `` tag without an `alt` attribute or bind it to a property which can be `null` or `undefined`. ## Does this PR introduce a breaking change? - [X] No Like all new extended diagnostics, if users set `defaultCategory: 'error'`, then this change may introduce a new error in their build. However, this is explicitly not supported per our [semver policy for extended diagnostics](https://angular.io/extended-diagnostics#semantic-versioning). This PR is targeting v15 anyways, so even in this situation, a breakage is expected by users. ## Other information Directives can technically bind `alt` attributes, for example `` _could_ be valid if `myImageDirective` sets the `alt` attribute. However, this is tricky to statically analyze and uncommon for the `alt` attribute in particular. This particular use cases is ignored for now, and will incorrectly show a warning. https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/47374 would provide more introspection functionality which would allow the compiler to more effectively filter out false positives from such a situation. Fixes #46669.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(compiler-cli): add `imgAltRequired` extended diagnostic" (#47485)

Issues.Title: [Feature Request] Currency Pipe: improved digit info options
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

common

### Description

A common way to display currencies (at least in US) is to omit the cents if the price is a round number, or to show two digits if the price is not a round number.
For example, for `3` dollars, `$3`, and for `3.1` dollar, `$3.10`.

There is no way to accomplish this with the current currency pipe, which only takes a range for the number of digits after the decimal. The only options either make the first price `$3.00` and the second `$3.10`, or the first price `$3` and the second `$3.1`.

### Proposed solution

Extend the `digitsInfo` format. Currently, the format is `{minIntegerDigits}.{minFractionDigits}-{maxFractionDigits}`.
As an alternative, we could offer `{minIntegerDigits}.{allowedFractionDigits1},{allowedFractionDigits2}[,...]`. So the `digitsInfo` for the format above would be `1.0,2`.

### Alternatives considered

Alternately, one could use an `*ngIf` to change out the element with the currency, and use two elements, each with a currency pipe to accomplish the above. Obviously, that is kind of messy.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Feature Request] Currency Pipe: improved digit info options" (#47479)

Issues.Title: issue with parseWorkspace "lint" warnings -  should be suppressable or have static configuration
Issues.Body:
### Command

other

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

< 14

### Description

With v14, devkit introduces advanced built-in linting of Workspace.
It will generate console warnings for each unknown node.
I understand it's usefulness for standard angular repositories.
However the current setup has some flaws that lead to endless console warnings in some situations.

At the moment, only option to suppress it is to call readJsonWorkspace with options.allowedProjectExtensions specifying all extra tags. 

## The issue

This is good, but it can only work if readJsonWorkspace is called appropriately by third-party API.
This is not always possible. For example when using schematics CLI or testing schematics, 
readJsonWorkspace will be called without any chance for customization.

In our case, running a schematic test suite results in the console becoming illegible by being floated by tens of thousands warnings, with no way to suppress them.

In other words: Each execution of SchematicTestRunner.runSchematicAsync will fetch workspace with standard configuration resulting in 100s of warnings.

## Proposed Solution A

Allow workspace to have an additional node named `extraProjectExtensions`.
Always merge its contents (Array<string>) into allowedProjectExtensions.

Benefits of this solution:
a) will always work
b) does not suppress *useful* warnings
c) it is easier to see what is going on because the setup is not hidden in any cli libraries but easily accessible in config.

## Proposed Solution B

Add a option to disable these warnings entirely.
For example a flag within workspace json, allowing to disable these checks.

Benefits:
a) simpler than Solution A

Cons:
b) MAY obfuscate errors by suppressing warnings

### Minimal Reproduction

Not a typical bug, but if anyone needs to see it for him/herself:

add a custom node to angular.json project, for example like nx does:
```json
"tags": ["env:frontend"]
```

set up a unit test executing SchematicTestRunner 

run it and see how each test generates warnings about the workspace containing invalid names.

### Exception or Error

```text
"Project extension with invalid name (xxx) found."
```


### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 14.2.1
Node: 16.17.0
Package Manager: npm 8.15.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 14.2.1
... animations, cdk, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core
... elements, forms, language-service, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, platform-server, router
... service-worker

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1402.2
@angular-devkit/build-angular   14.2.2
@angular-devkit/build-webpack   0.1402.2
@angular-devkit/core            14.2.2
@angular-devkit/schematics      14.2.2
@ngtools/webpack                14.2.2
@nguniversal/builders           14.2.0
@nguniversal/express-engine     14.2.0
@schematics/angular             14.2.3
rxjs                            7.5.4
typescript                      4.7.4
webpack                         5.74.0
```


### Anything else relevant?

This change is reason for https://github.com/nrwl/nx/issues/11138

Issues.Body: The global require function is not present in Node.js ESM mode. To support the eventual transition of the `@angular/cli` package to ESM, usage of the `require.resolve` function has been converted to use locally created `require` functions via `createRequire` from the `module` builtin.

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): use Browserslist to determine ECMA output
Issues.Body:
With this change we reduce the reliance on the TypeScript target compiler option to output a certain ECMA version. Instead we now use the browsers that are configured in the Browserslist configuration to determine which ECMA features and version are needed. This is done by passing the transpiled TypeScript to Babel preset-env.

**Note about useDefineForClassFields**: while setting this to `false` will output JavaScript which is not spec compliant, this is needed because TypeScript introduced class fields many years before it was ratified in TC39. The latest version of the spec have a different runtime behavior to TypeScript’s implementation but the same syntax. Therefore, we opt-out from using upcoming ECMA runtime behavior to better support the ECO system and libraries that depend on the non spec compliant output. One of biggest case is usages of the deprected `@Effect` decorator by NGRX which otherwise would cause runtime failures. Dropping `useDefineForClassFields` will be considered in a future major releases. For more information see: https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/issues/45995.

BREAKING CHANGE: Internally the Angular CLI now always set the TypeScript `target` to `ES2022` and `useDefineForClassFields` to `false` unless the target is set to `ES2022` or later in the TypeScript configuration. To control ECMA version and features use the Browerslist configuration.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): use Browserslist to determine ECMA output" (#23936)

Issues.Title: docs: clarify that version bumps must happen separately from the release PR
Issues.Body:
In `14.2.0`, we learned that we can't bump peer deps / `latest-versions.ts` in a release PR, because the released NPM artifact is actually built *before* an opportunity to edit the PR appears. We need to do a separate before the CLI release to make this change.

See: https://angular-team.slack.com/archives/C46U16D4Z/p1661482133013029

Hopefully I'm understanding how and why this works correctly, please let me know if I'm missing anything or if my wording is confusing.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "docs: clarify that version bumps must happen separately from the release PR" (#23921)

Issues.Title: index.html is rebuilt infinitely in watch mode, if it is right in the `outputPath` path
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

14.2.1

### Description

If `index` path in `angular.json` lies right under the `outputPath` (ex. `index` is `public/index.html` and `outputPath` is `public`), it will cause infinite rebuilding of index.html when the `--watch` option is used.

Probably caused by #23852.

### Minimal Reproduction

1. Create a new workspace with `ng new testapp` with default settings.
2. Open `testapp/angular.json` and change the `outputPath` option to `src`.
3. Run `cd testapp && ng build --watch --no-delete-output-path` and wait for initial build to finish.
4. Observe the result.

### Exception or Error

_No response_

### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 14.2.2
Node: 14.19.1
Package Manager: yarn 1.22.10 
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 14.2.2
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router, upgrade

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1402.1
@angular-devkit/build-angular   14.2.1
@angular-devkit/core            14.2.2
@angular-devkit/schematics      14.2.2
@schematics/angular             14.2.2
rxjs                            7.5.6
typescript                      4.6.4
webpack                         4.46.0
```


### Anything else relevant?

_No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "index.html is rebuilt infinitely in watch mode, if it is right in the `outputPath` path" (#23923)

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): remove environment files in new applications
Issues.Body:
This commit removes the usage of environment files and `fileReplacements` in new application projects. Previously, the environment files was used to distinguish between a prod build to invoke `enableProdMode`. The `enableProdMode` however needed only for the case of JIT mode in production mode, which is a rare case as JIT mode is recommanded to be used in production.

In the CLI, calling `enableProdMode` is not needed as `ngDevMode` it's set using the minifier.

**This change only affects the application generated by `ng new`. Environments are _not_ being removed, deprecated, or discouraged.**
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@schematics/angular): remove environment files in new applications" (#23931)

Issues.Title: build: use shared circleci dev-infra for common circleci code
Issues.Body:
This allows us to remove the `rebase-pr.js` script so that we can maintain this script in a single place.

NOTE: Here the script significantly from other repositories. i.e.

* The script currently just uses unauthenticated GitHub API calls to determine the base branches
   * The script in other repos (and in the orb) doesn't use GitHub API calls
* The script does not check for CircleCI changes.
   * The script in other repos (and in the orb) will complain if a PR runs with an outdated CircleCI config. i.e. changes are pushed but not rebased so that a PR could potentially miss checks.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: use shared circleci dev-infra for common circleci code" (#23929)

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): enable error on unknown properties and elements in tests
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist

Please check to confirm your PR fulfills the following requirements:

<!-- Please check all that apply using "x". -->

- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)

What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:

## What is the new behavior?

These new options have been introduced in Angular v14. The commit enables the options in a new project, as we did when we introduced the `destroyAfterOption`, with the same long-term goal to have these options enabled by default.

This is similar to #21300 which was done in the past to add `destroyAfterOption: true` by default.

This was discussed with @AndrewKushnir (who wants to discuss it in the next team sync meeting) and the idea would be to change these options to true by default and add a migration to ease the transition in v16 or later.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes

Issues.Title: fileReplacements support for browser-esbuild
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Description

The improved build times for experimental browser-esbuild are really promising, but absence of fileReplacements is a true blocker for workplaces with multiple environments, any enterprise at minimum. 

I took an initial look into this within the angular-cli project but didn't get far. It looks like esbuild's hooks are only available _after_ the angular-typescript program has been generated.

I am curious to know what other options there are and whether this is something the angular team is looking into. 

### Describe the solution you'd like

fileReplacements support for browser-esbuild

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Unclear whether esbuild can support this out of the box, perhaps support has to come from the compiler itself.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "fileReplacements support for browser-esbuild" (#23915)

Issues.Title: Bug (Dialog Component) accessibility issue : Aria hidden element must not be focusable or contain focusable elements
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Following Accessibility issue reported in angular dialog component when I ran accessibility scan using "Axe Dev tools"

Environment

Issues.Title: bug(MatMenu): focusFirstItem is not working
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

13.3.1

### Description

We are opening some matMenus programmatically which sets a visible focus on the first element of the menu. To be consistent we also focus the first element manually when the users opens the menu via click. 
With Angular 14 this function does not work anymore. 

### Reproduction

### Expected Behavior

If I call focusFirstItem(), the first item in the menu should be in correct focus.
As the default parameter is 'program' and programmatic opening of menus sets usually the visible focus, same as 'keyboard' parameter.

### Actual Behavior

focusFirstItem() does nothing

Issues.Title: fix(material/core): use full theme config definitions to prebuilt themes
Issues.Body:
Add typography and density keys to the prebuilt theming files. 

While it's probably safe to default typography to `typography.define-typography-config()`, this is a good intermediate step to enable strict theme configs internally. If it can be proven safe to add a real typography config, we can change it.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(material/core): use full theme config definitions to prebuilt themes" (#25656)

Issues.Title: fix(material/core): add optional warning for incomplete themes
Issues.Body:
Add a flag that can be transformed to "true" internally that produces an error if users call a theming function with an incomplete map.

For example, calling `mat.button-typography($theme)` that doesn't have `typography` will error. 

Another example, calling `mat.button-theme($theme)` without color, typography, and density will error.

For cases where users do not want to include certain styles, e.g. typography, they should directly call "-color()" and "-density()" and skip "-typography()"

The intent of this is to standardize theming configurations internally so that all apps explicitly declare what they want to include in their theming, making it more clear what they are not including as well. All apps will default to `typography: null` or `density: 0` if it is missing in their theme config
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(material/core): add optional warning for incomplete themes" (#25654)

Issues.Title: bug(overlay): Compiler error using OverlayRef when implementing ScrollStrategy's attach method when in strict mode
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

13.x

### Description

A related issue but the reporter was using `PositionStrategy` which for some reason works even in strict mode: https://github.com/angular/components/issues/25098

This issue is describing another issue that occurs when trying to implement `ScrollStrategy` in strict mode. You can't use `OverlayRef` as that will lead to the compiler error shown below. A workaround is to use `any` instead.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Set strict mode to `true` in tsconfig
2. Try to implement `ScrollStrategy` using `OverlayRef`

[Repro on StackBlitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-d5ewhx?file=tsconfig.json,src%2Fapp%2Fcustom-strategy.ts)

(On StackBlitz I noticed when opening the link I sometimes have to set strict to false then back to true for the problem to appear)

### Expected Behavior

Either `OverlayReference` should be exported, or at least it should be compat with `OverlayRef` even in strict mode in `ScrollStrategy`.
Also it's a bit confusing when you look at the `attach` signature (or you run the "Implement interface" action) and you find `OverlayReference` which can't be imported. There's no easy way to tell you actually need to change it to `OverlayRef`. This should be somehow documented on the method.

### Actual Behavior

We get the following compiler error:
```
Property 'attach' in type 'Some' is not assignable to the same property in base type 'ScrollStrategy'.
  Type '(overlayRef: OverlayRef) => void' is not assignable to type '(overlayRef: OverlayReference) => void'.
    Types of parameters 'overlayRef' and 'overlayRef' are incompatible.
      Type 'OverlayReference' is missing the following properties from type 'OverlayRef': _portalOutlet, _host, _pane, _config, and 29 more.
```

### Environment

- Angular: 14.2.2
- CDK/Material: 14.2.2
- Browser(s): Irrelevant
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows

`ng version`:
```
Angular CLI: 14.2.3
Node: 18.4.0 (Unsupported)
Package Manager: npm 8.12.1
OS: win32 x64
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(overlay): Compiler error using OverlayRef when implementing ScrollStrategy's attach method when in strict mode" (#25650)

Issues.Title: bug(matExpansionPanel): mat-expansion-panel not collapsed on IOS v13.2.1 safari
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

I opened an angular website that uses some mat-expansion-panels on an iPhone using IOS v13.2.1. I navigated to a page that uses some `mat-expansion-panel` and on this page every panel was already opened and i can't close them. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/58427793/190645015-03066685-593e-4902-9cc2-35f906d5160f.png)

I tried do debug it and saw that after clicking on the header part this error appears in the console:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/58427793/190643183-0b5a208f-d373-4f5d-be47-fab7df56df75.png)


### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. open safari on an IOS device using version 13.2.1
2. open an angular website
3. navigate to a page that uses `mat-expansion-panel`


### Expected Behavior

I was expecting, that the `mat-expansion-panel` would also work on older IOS version. In this case all the panels should have been closed on accessing the app and after clicking on them they should have opened.

### Actual Behavior

All `mat-expansion-panels` were already opened and i wasn't able to close them. The console was showing the mentioned error above, after clicking on the header part of the `mat-expansion-panel`.

### Environment

- Angular: 14.2.1
- CDK/Material: 14.2.0
- Browser(s): Safari
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): IOS v13.2.1
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(matExpansionPanel): mat-expansion-panel not collapsed on IOS v13.2.1 safari" (#25647)
